xv6/fs.c

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 // File system implementation.  Four layers:
00002 //   + Blocks: allocator for raw disk blocks.
00003 //   + Files: inode allocator, reading, writing, metadata.
00004 //   + Directories: inode with special contents (list of other inodes!)
00005 //   + Names: paths like /usr/rtm/xv6/fs.c for convenient naming.
00006 //
00007 // Disk layout is: superblock, inodes, block in-use bitmap, data blocks.
00008 //
00009 // This file contains the low-level file system manipulation 
00010 // routines.  The (higher-level) system call implementations
00011 // are in sysfile.c.
00012 
00013 #include "types.h"
00014 #include "defs.h"
00015 #include "param.h"
00016 #include "stat.h"
00017 #include "mmu.h"
00018 #include "proc.h"
00019 #include "spinlock.h"
00020 #include "buf.h"
00021 #include "fs.h"
00022 #include "file.h"

00024 #define min(a, b) ((a) < (b) ? (a) : (b))
00025 static void itrunc(struct inode*);

00027 // Read the super block.
00028 static void
00029 readsb(int dev, struct superblock *sb)
00030 {
00031   struct buf *bp;
00032   
00033   bp = bread(dev, 1);
00034   memmove(sb, bp->data, sizeof(*sb));
00035   brelse(bp);
00036 }
00037 
00038 // Zero a block.
00039 static void
00040 bzero(int dev, int bno)
00041 {
00042   struct buf *bp;
00043   
00044   bp = bread(dev, bno);
00045   memset(bp->data, 0, BSIZE);
00046   bwrite(bp);
00047   brelse(bp);
00048 }
00049 
00050 // Blocks. 
00051 
00052 // Allocate a disk block.
00053 static uint
00054 balloc(uint dev)
00055 {
00056   int b, bi, m;
00057   struct buf *bp;
00058   struct superblock sb;
00059 
00060   bp = 0;
00061   readsb(dev, &sb);
00062   for(b = 0; b < sb.size; b += BPB){
00063     bp = bread(dev, BBLOCK(b, sb.ninodes));
00064     for(bi = 0; bi < BPB; bi++){
00065       m = 1 << (bi % 8);
00066       if((bp->data[bi/8] & m) == 0){  // Is block free?
00067         bp->data[bi/8] |= m;  // Mark block in use on disk.
00068         bwrite(bp);
00069         brelse(bp);
00070         return b + bi;
00071       }
00072     }
00073     brelse(bp);
00074   }
00075   panic("balloc: out of blocks");
00076 }
00077 
00078 // Free a disk block.
00079 static void
00080 bfree(int dev, uint b)
00081 {
00082   struct buf *bp;
00083   struct superblock sb;
00084   int bi, m;
00085 
00086   bzero(dev, b);
00087 
00088   readsb(dev, &sb);
00089   bp = bread(dev, BBLOCK(b, sb.ninodes));
00090   bi = b % BPB;
00091   m = 1 << (bi % 8);
00092   if((bp->data[bi/8] & m) == 0)
00093     panic("freeing free block");
00094   bp->data[bi/8] &= ~m;  // Mark block free on disk.
00095   bwrite(bp);
00096   brelse(bp);
00097 }
00098 
00099 // Inodes.
00100 //
00101 // An inode is a single, unnamed file in the file system.
00102 // The inode disk structure holds metadata (the type, device numbers,
00103 // and data size) along with a list of blocks where the associated
00104 // data can be found.
00105 //
00106 // The inodes are laid out sequentially on disk immediately after
00107 // the superblock.  The kernel keeps a cache of the in-use
00108 // on-disk structures to provide a place for synchronizing access
00109 // to inodes shared between multiple processes.
00110 // 
00111 // ip->ref counts the number of pointer references to this cached
00112 // inode; references are typically kept in struct file and in proc->cwd.
00113 // When ip->ref falls to zero, the inode is no longer cached.
00114 // It is an error to use an inode without holding a reference to it.
00115 //
00116 // Processes are only allowed to read and write inode
00117 // metadata and contents when holding the inode's lock,
00118 // represented by the I_BUSY flag in the in-memory copy.
00119 // Because inode locks are held during disk accesses, 
00120 // they are implemented using a flag rather than with
00121 // spin locks.  Callers are responsible for locking
00122 // inodes before passing them to routines in this file; leaving
00123 // this responsibility with the caller makes it possible for them
00124 // to create arbitrarily-sized atomic operations.
00125 //
00126 // To give maximum control over locking to the callers, 
00127 // the routines in this file that return inode pointers 
00128 // return pointers to *unlocked* inodes.  It is the callers'
00129 // responsibility to lock them before using them.  A non-zero
00130 // ip->ref keeps these unlocked inodes in the cache.
00131 
00132 struct {
00133   struct spinlock lock;
00134   struct inode inode[NINODE];
00135 } icache;
00136 
00137 void
00138 iinit(void)
00139 {
00140   initlock(&icache.lock, "icache");
00141 }
00142 
00143 static struct inode* iget(uint dev, uint inum);
00144 
00145 // Allocate a new inode with the given type on device dev.
00146 struct inode*
00147 ialloc(uint dev, short type)
00148 {
00149   int inum;
00150   struct buf *bp;
00151   struct dinode *dip;
00152   struct superblock sb;
00153 
00154   readsb(dev, &sb);
00155   for(inum = 1; inum < sb.ninodes; inum++){  // loop over inode blocks
00156     bp = bread(dev, IBLOCK(inum));
00157     dip = (struct dinode*)bp->data + inum%IPB;
00158     if(dip->type == 0){  // a free inode
00159       memset(dip, 0, sizeof(*dip));
00160       dip->type = type;
00161       bwrite(bp);   // mark it allocated on the disk
00162       brelse(bp);
00163       return iget(dev, inum);
00164     }
00165     brelse(bp);
00166   }
00167   panic("ialloc: no inodes");
00168 }
00169 
00170 // Copy inode, which has changed, from memory to disk.
00171 void
00172 iupdate(struct inode *ip)
00173 {
00174   struct buf *bp;
00175   struct dinode *dip;
00176 
00177   bp = bread(ip->dev, IBLOCK(ip->inum));
00178   dip = (struct dinode*)bp->data + ip->inum%IPB;
00179   dip->type = ip->type;
00180   dip->major = ip->major;
00181   dip->minor = ip->minor;
00182   dip->nlink = ip->nlink;
00183   dip->size = ip->size;
00184   memmove(dip->addrs, ip->addrs, sizeof(ip->addrs));
00185   bwrite(bp);
00186   brelse(bp);
00187 }
00188 
00189 // Find the inode with number inum on device dev
00190 // and return the in-memory copy.
00191 static struct inode*
00192 iget(uint dev, uint inum)
00193 {
00194   struct inode *ip, *empty;
00195 
00196   acquire(&icache.lock);
00197 
00198   // Try for cached inode.
00199   empty = 0;
00200   for(ip = &icache.inode[0]; ip < &icache.inode[NINODE]; ip++){
00201     if(ip->ref > 0 && ip->dev == dev && ip->inum == inum){
00202       ip->ref++;
00203       release(&icache.lock);
00204       return ip;
00205     }
00206     if(empty == 0 && ip->ref == 0)    // Remember empty slot.
00207       empty = ip;
00208   }
00209 
00210   // Allocate fresh inode.
00211   if(empty == 0)
00212     panic("iget: no inodes");
00213 
00214   ip = empty;
00215   ip->dev = dev;
00216   ip->inum = inum;
00217   ip->ref = 1;
00218   ip->flags = 0;
00219   release(&icache.lock);
00220 
00221   return ip;
00222 }
00223 
00224 // Increment reference count for ip.
00225 // Returns ip to enable ip = idup(ip1) idiom.
00226 struct inode*
00227 idup(struct inode *ip)
00228 {
00229   acquire(&icache.lock);
00230   ip->ref++;
00231   release(&icache.lock);
00232   return ip;
00233 }
00234 
00235 // Lock the given inode.
00236 void
00237 ilock(struct inode *ip)
00238 {
00239   struct buf *bp;
00240   struct dinode *dip;
00241 
00242   if(ip == 0 || ip->ref < 1)
00243     panic("ilock");
00244 
00245   acquire(&icache.lock);
00246   while(ip->flags & I_BUSY)
00247     sleep(ip, &icache.lock);
00248   ip->flags |= I_BUSY;
00249   release(&icache.lock);
00250 
00251   if(!(ip->flags & I_VALID)){
00252     bp = bread(ip->dev, IBLOCK(ip->inum));
00253     dip = (struct dinode*)bp->data + ip->inum%IPB;
00254     ip->type = dip->type;
00255     ip->major = dip->major;
00256     ip->minor = dip->minor;
00257     ip->nlink = dip->nlink;
00258     ip->size = dip->size;
00259     memmove(ip->addrs, dip->addrs, sizeof(ip->addrs));
00260     brelse(bp);
00261     ip->flags |= I_VALID;
00262     if(ip->type == 0)
00263       panic("ilock: no type");
00264   }
00265 }
00266 
00267 // Unlock the given inode.
00268 void
00269 iunlock(struct inode *ip)
00270 {
00271   if(ip == 0 || !(ip->flags & I_BUSY) || ip->ref < 1)
00272     panic("iunlock");
00273 
00274   acquire(&icache.lock);
00275   ip->flags &= ~I_BUSY;
00276   wakeup(ip);
00277   release(&icache.lock);
00278 }
00279 
00280 // Caller holds reference to unlocked ip.  Drop reference.
00281 void
00282 iput(struct inode *ip)
00283 {
00284   acquire(&icache.lock);
00285   if(ip->ref == 1 && (ip->flags & I_VALID) && ip->nlink == 0){
00286     // inode is no longer used: truncate and free inode.
00287     if(ip->flags & I_BUSY)
00288       panic("iput busy");
00289     ip->flags |= I_BUSY;
00290     release(&icache.lock);
00291     itrunc(ip);
00292     ip->type = 0;
00293     iupdate(ip);
00294     acquire(&icache.lock);
00295     ip->flags = 0;
00296     wakeup(ip);
00297   }
00298   ip->ref--;
00299   release(&icache.lock);
00300 }
00301 
00302 // Common idiom: unlock, then put.
00303 void
00304 iunlockput(struct inode *ip)
00305 {
00306   iunlock(ip);
00307   iput(ip);
00308 }
00309 
00310 // Inode contents
00311 //
00312 // The contents (data) associated with each inode is stored
00313 // in a sequence of blocks on the disk.  The first NDIRECT blocks
00314 // are listed in ip->addrs[].  The next NINDIRECT blocks are 
00315 // listed in the block ip->addrs[INDIRECT].
00316 
00317 // Return the disk block address of the nth block in inode ip.
00318 // If there is no such block, bmap allocates one.
00319 static uint
00320 bmap(struct inode *ip, uint bn)
00321 {
00322   uint addr, *a;
00323   struct buf *bp;
00324 
00325   if(bn < NDIRECT){
00326     if((addr = ip->addrs[bn]) == 0)
00327       ip->addrs[bn] = addr = balloc(ip->dev);
00328     return addr;
00329   }
00330   bn -= NDIRECT;
00331 
00332   if(bn < NINDIRECT){
00333     // Load indirect block, allocating if necessary.
00334     if((addr = ip->addrs[NDIRECT]) == 0)
00335       ip->addrs[NDIRECT] = addr = balloc(ip->dev);
00336     bp = bread(ip->dev, addr);
00337     a = (uint*)bp->data;
00338     if((addr = a[bn]) == 0){
00339       a[bn] = addr = balloc(ip->dev);
00340       bwrite(bp);
00341     }
00342     brelse(bp);
00343     return addr;
00344   }
00345 
00346   panic("bmap: out of range");
00347 }
00348 
00349 // Truncate inode (discard contents).
00350 // Only called after the last dirent referring
00351 // to this inode has been erased on disk.
00352 static void
00353 itrunc(struct inode *ip)
00354 {
00355   int i, j;
00356   struct buf *bp;
00357   uint *a;
00358 
00359   for(i = 0; i < NDIRECT; i++){
00360     if(ip->addrs[i]){
00361       bfree(ip->dev, ip->addrs[i]);
00362       ip->addrs[i] = 0;
00363     }
00364   }
00365   
00366   if(ip->addrs[NDIRECT]){
00367     bp = bread(ip->dev, ip->addrs[NDIRECT]);
00368     a = (uint*)bp->data;
00369     for(j = 0; j < NINDIRECT; j++){
00370       if(a[j])
00371         bfree(ip->dev, a[j]);
00372     }
00373     brelse(bp);
00374     bfree(ip->dev, ip->addrs[NDIRECT]);
00375     ip->addrs[NDIRECT] = 0;
00376   }
00377 
00378   ip->size = 0;
00379   iupdate(ip);
00380 }

00382 // Copy stat information from inode.
00383 void
00384 stati(struct inode *ip, struct stat *st)
00385 {
00386   st->dev = ip->dev;
00387   st->ino = ip->inum;
00388   st->type = ip->type;
00389   st->nlink = ip->nlink;
00390   st->size = ip->size;
00391 }
00392 
00393 // Read data from inode.
00394 int
00395 readi(struct inode *ip, char *dst, uint off, uint n)
00396 {
00397   uint tot, m;
00398   struct buf *bp;
00399 
00400   if(ip->type == T_DEV){
00401     if(ip->major < 0 || ip->major >= NDEV || !devsw[ip->major].read)
00402       return -1;
00403     return devsw[ip->major].read(ip, dst, n);
00404   }
00405 
00406   if(off > ip->size || off + n < off)
00407     return -1;
00408   if(off + n > ip->size)
00409     n = ip->size - off;
00410 
00411   for(tot=0; tot<n; tot+=m, off+=m, dst+=m){
00412     bp = bread(ip->dev, bmap(ip, off/BSIZE));
00413     m = min(n - tot, BSIZE - off%BSIZE);
00414     memmove(dst, bp->data + off%BSIZE, m);
00415     brelse(bp);
00416   }
00417   return n;
00418 }
00419 
00420 // Write data to inode.
00421 int
00422 writei(struct inode *ip, char *src, uint off, uint n)
00423 {
00424   uint tot, m;
00425   struct buf *bp;
00426 
00427   if(ip->type == T_DEV){
00428     if(ip->major < 0 || ip->major >= NDEV || !devsw[ip->major].write)
00429       return -1;
00430     return devsw[ip->major].write(ip, src, n);
00431   }
00432 
00433   if(off > ip->size || off + n < off)
00434     return -1;
00435   if(off + n > MAXFILE*BSIZE)
00436     n = MAXFILE*BSIZE - off;
00437 
00438   for(tot=0; tot<n; tot+=m, off+=m, src+=m){
00439     bp = bread(ip->dev, bmap(ip, off/BSIZE));
00440     m = min(n - tot, BSIZE - off%BSIZE);
00441     memmove(bp->data + off%BSIZE, src, m);
00442     bwrite(bp);
00443     brelse(bp);
00444   }
00445 
00446   if(n > 0 && off > ip->size){
00447     ip->size = off;
00448     iupdate(ip);
00449   }
00450   return n;
00451 }

00455 int
00456 namecmp(const char *s, const char *t)
00457 {
00458   return strncmp(s, t, DIRSIZ);
00459 }
00460 
00461 // Look for a directory entry in a directory.
00462 // If found, set *poff to byte offset of entry.
00463 // Caller must have already locked dp.
00464 struct inode*
00465 dirlookup(struct inode *dp, char *name, uint *poff)
00466 {
00467   uint off, inum;
00468   struct buf *bp;
00469   struct dirent *de;
00470 
00471   if(dp->type != T_DIR)
00472     panic("dirlookup not DIR");
00473 
00474   for(off = 0; off < dp->size; off += BSIZE){
00475     bp = bread(dp->dev, bmap(dp, off / BSIZE));
00476     for(de = (struct dirent*)bp->data;
00477         de < (struct dirent*)(bp->data + BSIZE);
00478         de++){
00479       if(de->inum == 0)
00480         continue;
00481       if(namecmp(name, de->name) == 0){
00482         // entry matches path element
00483         if(poff)
00484           *poff = off + (uchar*)de - bp->data;
00485         inum = de->inum;
00486         brelse(bp);
00487         return iget(dp->dev, inum);
00488       }
00489     }
00490     brelse(bp);
00491   }
00492   return 0;
00493 }
00494 
00495 // Write a new directory entry (name, inum) into the directory dp.
00496 int
00497 dirlink(struct inode *dp, char *name, uint inum)
00498 {
00499   int off;
00500   struct dirent de;
00501   struct inode *ip;
00502 
00503   // Check that name is not present.
00504   if((ip = dirlookup(dp, name, 0)) != 0){
00505     iput(ip);
00506     return -1;
00507   }
00508 
00509   // Look for an empty dirent.
00510   for(off = 0; off < dp->size; off += sizeof(de)){
00511     if(readi(dp, (char*)&de, off, sizeof(de)) != sizeof(de))
00512       panic("dirlink read");
00513     if(de.inum == 0)
00514       break;
00515   }
00516 
00517   strncpy(de.name, name, DIRSIZ);
00518   de.inum = inum;
00519   if(writei(dp, (char*)&de, off, sizeof(de)) != sizeof(de))
00520     panic("dirlink");
00521   
00522   return 0;
00523 }
00524 
00525 // Paths
00526 
00527 // Copy the next path element from path into name.
00528 // Return a pointer to the element following the copied one.
00529 // The returned path has no leading slashes,
00530 // so the caller can check *path=='\0' to see if the name is the last one.
00531 // If no name to remove, return 0.
00532 //
00533 // Examples:
00534 //   skipelem("a/bb/c", name) = "bb/c", setting name = "a"
00535 //   skipelem("///a//bb", name) = "bb", setting name = "a"
00536 //   skipelem("a", name) = "", setting name = "a"
00537 //   skipelem("", name) = skipelem("////", name) = 0
00538 //
00539 static char*
00540 skipelem(char *path, char *name)
00541 {
00542   char *s;
00543   int len;
00544 
00545   while(*path == '/')
00546     path++;
00547   if(*path == 0)
00548     return 0;
00549   s = path;
00550   while(*path != '/' && *path != 0)
00551     path++;
00552   len = path - s;
00553   if(len >= DIRSIZ)
00554     memmove(name, s, DIRSIZ);
00555   else {
00556     memmove(name, s, len);
00557     name[len] = 0;
00558   }
00559   while(*path == '/')
00560     path++;
00561   return path;
00562 }
00563 
00564 // Look up and return the inode for a path name.
00565 // If parent != 0, return the inode for the parent and copy the final
00566 // path element into name, which must have room for DIRSIZ bytes.
00567 static struct inode*
00568 namex(char *path, int nameiparent, char *name)
00569 {
00570   struct inode *ip, *next;
00571 
00572   if(*path == '/')
00573     ip = iget(ROOTDEV, ROOTINO);
00574   else
00575     ip = idup(proc->cwd);
00576 
00577   while((path = skipelem(path, name)) != 0){
00578     ilock(ip);
00579     if(ip->type != T_DIR){
00580       iunlockput(ip);
00581       return 0;
00582     }
00583     if(nameiparent && *path == '\0'){
00584       // Stop one level early.
00585       iunlock(ip);
00586       return ip;
00587     }
00588     if((next = dirlookup(ip, name, 0)) == 0){
00589       iunlockput(ip);
00590       return 0;
00591     }
00592     iunlockput(ip);
00593     ip = next;
00594   }
00595   if(nameiparent){
00596     iput(ip);
00597     return 0;
00598   }
00599   return ip;
00600 }
00601 
00602 struct inode*
00603 namei(char *path)
00604 {
00605   char name[DIRSIZ];
00606   return namex(path, 0, name);
00607 }
00608 
00609 struct inode*
00610 nameiparent(char *path, char *name)
00611 {
00612   return namex(path, 1, name);
00613 }
